[Cross post from Math overflow & categories mailing list.]

Let X be a locale. Then there is the Vietoris locale construction, V, introduced by Johnstone (it's in Stone Spaces, but see also the 1985 paper, 'Vietoris Locales and Localic Semilattices'). The functor V:Loc→Loc is something like taking the locale of all 'finite' sublocales; e.g., if X is discrete then the points of V(X) are the finite subsets of X.  In his 1985 paper Johnstone alludes to the fact that if X is compact then so is V(X). But the proof, which is not explicit in the paper, uses a transfinite induction. I believe there is a much simpler proof, but have not found any references to this in the literature. Does anyone know about this specific result being published in the last 40[!] years?

Thanks,
Christopher
Graham Manuell has marked this topic as unresolved.

I don't know if this has been proved in the literature, but if XXX is compact Hausdorff, isn't the Vietoris locale of XXX the patch topology of SX\mathbb{S}^XSX? This would imply that it is compact Hausdorff.

Thanks Graham. I'd have to think about that specific point. It rings true as some of my thinking has been towards seeing the opens of V(X) as a splitting in the same way that the patch can be constructed as a splitting (interestingly, using a dcpo idempotent for general locales X, for which I think I was going to look at your paper that expresses the localic surjection of the splitting in such a circumstances, and moreover describes the splitting locale's presentation, I think?).

Of course, we know preservation by V:Loc->Loc of compact Hausdorffness from Stone Spaces - it was the preservation of compactness absent anything else that I was after. It's not really a 'big' result - it's a bit like how binary Tychonoff becomes straight forward once you use the preframe presentation of the (opens of) locale product. There's a similar result in Vicker's paper on connected Vietoris about the preservation of openness. I just wanted to see if anyone else had actually published anything on this before I wrote anything up.

@Graham Manuell - and anyone else who is interested - so I was not aware that the Vietoris on XXX can be viewed as the patch of SX\mathbb{S}^XSX (for compact Hausdorff XXX). That's nice and, indeed, in the classical literature as you pointed out separately. I think I have a neat general proof:

Let AAA be a set (=discrete locale). Then PL(A)≅SAP_L(A) \cong \mathbb{S}^APL​(A)≅SA (e.g. Vickers). Recalling that V(A)V(A)V(A) embeds (by construction) in PL(A)×PU(A)P_L(A) \times P_U(A)PL​(A)×PU​(A), say via (j,i)(j,i)(j,i) then we can construct:

ϕ:SVA≅PL(VA)→PL(i)PL(PU(A))≅SSA≅SPLA→SjSVA\phi:\mathbb{S}^{VA} \cong P_L(VA) \rightarrow^{P_L(i)} P_L(P_U(A)) \cong \mathbb{S}^{\mathbb{S}^A} \cong \mathbb{S}^{P_L A} \rightarrow^{\mathbb{S}^j} \mathbb{S}^{VA}ϕ:SVA≅PL​(VA)→PL​(i)PL​(PU​(A))≅SSA≅SPL​A→SjSVA

recalling that VAVAVA is discrete for the first bit (so that PL(VA)≅SVAP_L(VA) \cong \mathbb{S}^{VA}PL​(VA)≅SVA). But you can unwind to see (I hope!) that ϕ\phiϕ sends any open of VAVAVA to its upper closure (using the order on VAVAVA). The split must be the opens of Idl(VA)Idl(VA)Idl(VA) and of (the opens of ) PL(A)P_L(A)PL​(A) , so we have Idl(VA)≅PLAIdl(VA) \cong P_LAIdl(VA)≅PL​A for discrete AAA.

Now, of course, this is an incredibly long winded way of proving the incredibly well know and basic fact: idl(FA)=idl(FA)= idl(FA)= the power set of AAA, where FAFAFA is the set of finite subsets of AAA. But the point of knowing a purely localic proof of PLA≅Idl(VA)P_L A \cong Idl(VA)PL​A≅Idl(VA) for discrete AAA is the we can then appeal to compact Hausdorff/discrete duality: PU(X)≅Idl(VX)P_U(X) \cong Idl(VX)PU​(X)≅Idl(VX) for compact Hausdorff XXX. And since we know SX≅PU(X)\mathbb{S}^X \cong P_U(X)SX≅PU​(X) we get that Patch(SX)≅V(X)Patch(\mathbb{S}^X) \cong V(X)Patch(SX)≅V(X) as patch reverses ideal completion!
@Christopher Townsend Nice. How do you get the first isomorphism in the definition of ϕ\phiϕ formally?

Graham Manuell said:

Christopher Townsend Nice. How do you get the first isomorphism in the definition of ϕ\phiϕ formally?

VAVAVA is discrete - so apply SX≅PL(X)\mathbb{S}^X \cong P_L(X)SX≅PL​(X) for any discrete XXX*. That VAVAVA is discrete for discrete AAA follows by applying (formally) the standard join-coverage result using that the finite diagonals on AAA are open. (This was really the original question: is this step written down for the nullary diagonal A→1A \rightarrow 1A→1? I now think it sort of is in Vickers' paper on the connected Vietoris, though not 'formal' there, easily adapted to become formal. ).

(Note: I probably should not have used the notation IdlIdlIdl when talking about the compact Hausdorff dual to discrete IdlIdlIdl...)

  • actually is the question how to get SX=PL(X)\mathbb{S}^X = P_L(X)SX=PL​(X) formally for discrete XXX? That's laboured in my paper on 'Aspects of Slice Stability in Locale Theory'., Prop 4.2.4; again not doing much more than just repeating Vickers original proof.
I meant how do you get VAV AVA is discrete in a way that dualises to the compact Hausdorff case, but yes, as you say, I guess that was the original question.

MATH_VIETORIS.jpeg
i.e. just use that ∃X\exists_X∃X​ exists to show ∃VX\exists_{VX}∃VX​ must exist by application of (formal!) suplattice coverage.
Showing that the open diagonal is preserved is similar, using the meet semi lattice operation on PU(X)P_U(X)PU​(X).

I hope to write this up properly in due course - treat with caution!
